I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   The  proposed  capacity  development  technical  assistance  (TA)  is  consistent  with  the 
South  Asia  regional  cooperation  strategy,  2011–20151 and  the  Asian  Development  Bank’s 
(ADB’s) country partnership strategy for Bangladesh,2 both of which place high priority  on 
regional  connectivity  and  trade  facilitation  projects.  The  TA  was  conceptualized  following 
consultations conducted for South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) trade 
facilitation from October 2012 to March 2013, and was included in ADB’s South Asia regional 
cooperation operations business plan, 2013-2015.3 
 
2.  At the meetings of the SASEC trade facilitation and transport working group (TFTWG) in 
2010–2012, the governments of SASEC countries4 requested continued support from ADB on 
SASEC  trade  facilitation.  At  the  SASEC  TFTWG  meeting  held  in  Thimphu,  Bhutan  on  8 
November  2012,  SASEC  country  delegations  (i)  agreed  to  expand  assistance  to  trade 
facilitation through additional TA to ensure that full support is provided to ongoing initiatives, and 
(ii)  requested  ADB  to  explore  the  possibility  of  providing  TA  to  respond  to  specific  trade 
facilitation needs of SASEC countries. 
 
3.  An ADB mission visited Dhaka in January 2013 to discuss with the Government of 
Bangladesh the assistance required with regard to the participation of Bangladesh in SASEC 
trade  facilitation  initiatives,  including  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  and  activities  of  the 
proposed TA. Subsequent consultations with the government resulted in agreement on the TA’s 
implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference. At the 
SASEC customs subgroup meeting in Bangkok in March 2013, representatives of SASEC 
countries, ADB, and the World Customs Organization (WCO) discussed priority training needs 
to  support  customs  modernization  efforts  in  SASEC  member  countries.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework of the TA is in Appendix 1.5  
  
II.  ISSUES 
4.  The Doing Business Report 20136 by the World Bank estimates that it takes 25 days in 
Bangladesh to complete all procedures related to export and 34 days for import. Costs of 
transporting a 20-foot container average $1,025 for export and $1,430 for import. High costs 
and time to trade greatly reduce prospects for trade in Bangladesh and rank the country 119 on 
efficiency in trading across borders. Data indicate that a significant portion of the time needed to 
trade is due to institutional barriers, such as the time taken to prepare documentation and 
complete customs clearance. 
  
5.  Need to facilitate border clearance. The government needs to put in place the legal 
and regulatory framework to facilitate border formalities. The accession of Bangladesh to the 
Revised Kyoto Convention (RKC) 7 in September 2012 is an important first step in this direction. 
With the assistance of the WCO, the National Board of Revenue (NBR) of Bangladesh has

2   
finalized a strategic plan of action for customs for 2013–2016, which lists high-priority actions 
including modernizing and automating customs procedures, applying risk management tools, 
and developing a national single window in line with the RKC. Many of the required policy 
actions to implement the RKC and the strategic action plan for customs are included as tranche 
conditions under the ADB-assisted SASEC Trade Facilitation Program loan in Bangladesh.8 
Initial  experience  in  implementing  the  Program  loan  suggests  that  the  government  needs 
assistance in ensuring that these tranche conditions are satisfied, and in putting in place the 
other  key  legal,  regulatory,  and  institutional  and  capacity  requirements  for  customs 
modernization and reforms in Bangladesh.9 
 
6.  The large volume of required documentation is a major impediment to the smooth flow of 
goods across borders. A large number of documents, multiple copies, and multiple signatures 
are required to undertake customs clearance. For example, exporting a standard container of 
goods requires six documents, while importing the same container of goods requires eight 
documents.10 Alignment of trade documents with international standards and harmonization of 
documents across agencies and/or ministries and across countries will reduce the burden on 
traders. 
 
7.  The absence of a structured risk management regime is another major impediment. 
Although about 10% of cargo needs to be inspected at the borders, inspection is mainly at the 
discretion of the senior management at customs stations. Risk-managed inspection on the basis 
of carefully drawn risk profiling is still absent. As a result, highly compliant traders are denied 
facilitation measures, such as pre-arrival clearance, post-clearance audit, and other methods for 
nonintrusive inspections. Valuation of goods is another major source of dispute at borders, 
which leads to goods being detained for a long time. 
 
8.  Lack of full customs automation. Bangladesh currently uses the Automated System 
for Customs Data (ASYCUDA)++ for the operation of customs. To date three ports— Benapole, 
Chittagong,  and  Dhaka—have  been  automated  through  the  adoption  of  ASYCUDA++.  In 
practice,  however,  automation  is  partial  at  best,  with  several  key  functions  still  conducted 
manually  and,  therefore,  with  low  levels  of  efficiency.  Procedures  in  all  other  ports  are 
conducted manually. This is followed by entry of ex-post data, which are collected on CD-ROMs 
and sent to the central customs office in Dhaka at the end of each month. This is an inefficient 
and  outdated  method  of  customs  data  management.  Under  the  present  system,  customs 
officers are unable to interface with the other border agencies, such as quarantine, immigration, 
and  the  Bangladesh  Land  Port  Authority,  which  use  other  systems. There  is  also  lack of 
connectivity with banks, freight forwarders, and importers and exporters. There is no pre-arrival 
declaration  or  advance  ruling  facility.  However,  Bangladesh  is  migrating  its  customs 
management  system  from  ASYCUDA++  to  ASYCUDA  World.  This  new  system  will  allow 
electronic data interchange system across customs stations and border agencies, an electronic 
national single window (NSW), and other e-customs facilities.  
 
9.  Need for enhanced trader access to information. One of the ongoing initiatives that 
the government is undertaking to promote accelerated trade and investment is to make key 
information on trade regulations and procedures easily available to the trading community. With 
initiative from the Ministry of Commerce, Bangladesh is in the process of developing a trade

portal that can be accessed through a website by traders and logistics operators. Private sector 
representatives in Bangladesh, including chambers of commerce, are also working actively to 
provide information to businesses, including on market access and bank and other finance 
opportunities. The government has requested ADB’s support in providing timely and relevant 
information to traders. 
 
10.  Bangladesh has made significant efforts to implement trade facilitation measures. With 
its accession to the RKC, the government has made a strong commitment to simplify and 
modernize customs laws, rules, and regulations, for which it needs technical assistance in 
various areas. This includes development of audit-based risk management systems, authorized 
economic operators, and measures to enhance the transparency and speed of transactions at 
borders. Through the SASEC Trade Facilitation Program loan (footnote 8), Bangladesh has also 
agreed to pilot a scalable NSW led by the NBR. To implement these policy actions, Bangladesh 
is in need of adequate resources and capacity to put the new systems in place.11 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA is a reduction in the time and cost needed to undertake trade in 
Bangladesh, which will be measured by faster export and import processes. The expected 
outcome  is  better  alignment  of  Bangladesh’s  customs  procedures  and  practices  with 
internationally accepted standards.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will have three outputs, as follows:  
(i)  Improved  border  clearance  mechanisms.  The  TA  will  assist  in  (a)  the 
formulation of necessary draft amendments to the Customs Act of 1969 and 
related legislation to make the act fully compliant with the general annex of the 
RKC; 12 (b)  the  conduct  of  a  regulatory  impact  assessment  of  proposed 
amendments  to  the  Customs  Act  and  related  legislation  to  make  them  fully 
compliant with the general annex; (c) establishment and operationalization of an 
authorized economic operators program;13 (d) formulation of updated standard 
operating procedures on risk management, post-clearance audit, assessment, 
physical  inspection,  and  nonintrusive  inspection  that  are  compliant  with  the 
Standards to Secure and Facilitate Global Trade (SAFE) Framework; and (e) the 
conduct of WCO time release studies covering major border-crossing points to 
serve as benchmarks for a performance monitoring system.14 In collaboration 
with the WCO, the TA will also help undertake training needs assessment on the 
above areas, and conduct technical training on identified training needs. The TA 
will also help identify and prepare future assistance by ADB in the above areas. 
                                                
11  Bhutan and Nepal are also in need of resources and capacity to put into effect the reforms being promoted under 
the SASEC Trade Facilitation Program loans and grants (footnote 9). 
12  ADB will coordinate with the International Finance Corporation in identifying the remaining gaps in similar work that 
it is supporting. 
13  ADB will coordinate with the United States Agency for International Development, which has plans to support 
similar work. 
14  The International Finance Corporation plans to carry out time release studies for Benapole and Chittagong ports, 
and the Dhaka Customs House.

4   
(ii)  Strengthened customs automation. Through provision of experts and, possibly, 
software  upgrades,  the  TA  will  support  the  NBR  in  the  transition  from 
ASYCUDA++ to ASYCUDA World, which will be interfaced with a pilot NSW 
program  connecting  with  the  electronic  data  processing  systems  of  selected 
agencies such as commerce and shipping. Associated technical training for the 
NSW on the application of ASYCUDA World will also be supported by the TA. 
Pilot testing of the new customs automation system will be carried out in at least 
two border checkpoints. 
(iii)  Enhanced trader access to information. The TA will strengthen the institutional 
arrangements for trade facilitation by ensuring greater participation of traders and 
other private sector stakeholders. It will also assist in the development of a trade 
portal, which is being undertaken by the Ministry of Commerce under the SASEC 
Trade Facilitation Program loan.15 The planned trade portal will be linked to 
ASYCUDA World. It will facilitate greater access of importers and exporters to 
trade data and information, especially for timely processing and issuance of 
import and/or export registration certificates and permits. 
 
13.  Attainment  of  the  TA’s  expected  impact  assumes  that  other  ongoing  and  planned 
complementary trade facilitation measures achieve their desired results, and that transport and 
border-crossing infrastructure along SASEC corridors has been upgraded or modernized. The 
outcome  of  the  TA  can  only  be  achieved  if  the  government  remains  committed  to  trade 
facilitation and subregional cooperation with other SASEC countries. A key risk is that influential 
groups with vested interests in the status quo lobby against custom reforms. The outputs of the 
TA can only be achieved if there is sufficient customs staff to carry out the needed customs 
reform. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.6 million, of which $1.5 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff and office accommodation, and 
other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months from  August 2013 to July 2015. The 
Regional Cooperation and Operations Coordination Division of the ADB South Asia Department 
(SARD), in cooperation with the ADB Bangladesh Resident Mission, will be the  executing 
agency for the TA as the TA will support Bangladesh’s participation in SASEC trade facilitation, 
for which SARD is the secretariat. The NBR will be the implementing agency. ADB will work 
closely with the WCO in implementing the TA. SARD will closely coordinate and regularly share 
information with the Customs and Tariff Bureau of the Ministry of Finance of Japan.  
 
16.  A total of 136.5 person-months of consultancy services will be engaged for the TA. 
Consultants will be engaged on an individual basis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for 
consultants are in Appendix 3. All disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with 
the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended). 
 
                                                
15  ADB will coordinate with IFC, which is assisting the Ministry of Commerce in developing the trade portal.

5 
17.  The TA will require 64.5 person-months of international consultancy services and 72.0 
person-months of national consultancy services, consisting of (i) international trade facilitation 
specialist (team leader) (20.0 person-months); (ii) international customs law specialist (10.0 
person-months);  (iii)  international  NSW  and  information  and  communication  technology 
specialist (12.0 person-months); (iv) international risk management and post-clearance audit 
specialist (12.0 person-months); (v) international transport and transit specialist (6.0 person-
months); (vi) international resource persons (4.5 person-months), who will participate in capacity 
building activities to discuss international good practices and provide advice on specific TA 
outputs;  (vii)  national  customs  specialists  (48.0  person-months);  and  (viii)  national  trade 
facilitation coordinating analyst (24.0 person-months). 
 
18.   Individual  consultants  will  be  engaged  because  of  (i)  the  diversity  of  tasks  to  be 
undertaken, (ii) the expected active involvement of focal points in the NBR of Bangladesh, and 
(iii) active overall management of the TA implementation by SARD staff.  
 
19.   The TA  will  be  monitored  and  coordinated  principally  through  the  meetings  of the 
SASEC TFTWG, the SASEC customs subgroup, and national and regional meetings to be held 
under the auspices of the TA.16 Evaluation of the TA’s outputs will be carried out by SARD 
through  the  annual  TA  implementation  review  mission  with  the  assistance  of  the  resident 
mission. 
 
20.   Good practices and lessons from the TA will be documented in the progress reports 
submitted to the SASEC TFTWG and posted on the SASEC website (www.sasec.asia). Good 
practices  and  lessons  learned  will  also  be  reported  during  meetings  of  ADB’s  Regional 
Cooperation and Integration Community of Practice. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
21.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,500,000  to  the 
Government of Bangladesh to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty 
Reduction for Supporting Participation in the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation 
Trade Facilitation Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
                                                
16  ADB is planning to implement a regional TA, which will, among other things, help coordinate the activities of the TA 
and planned TA projects for Bhutan and Nepal in support of the SASEC Trade Facilitation Program loans and 
grants.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Under the supervision of the South Asia Department (SARD) team overseeing technical 
assistance (TA) implementation, a team of individual international and national consultants will 
be engaged. International resource persons will also provide capacity building support through 
participation in workshops and training programs, and provide guidance in developing programs 
and reports. An estimated total of 136.5 person-months of consulting services (64.5 person-
months of international consultant inputs and 72.0 person-months of national consultant inputs) 
will be required over a 24-month period. The indicative person-month allocations and outline 
terms of reference for the consultants are as follows: 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Trade Facilitation Expert and Team Leader (20 person-months, intermittent)  
 
2.  The trade facilitation expert will assist SARD staff in the day-to-day management of the 
entire project throughout its duration and will actively guide and participate in all activities. The 
expert  should  have  previous  team  leader  experience  and  extensive  knowledge  of  and 
experience in implementing trade facilitation projects in a developing country context, including 
the  Revised  Kyoto  Convention  (RKC),  the  SAFE  Framework  of  Standards  to  Secure  and 
Facilitate  Global  Trade  (SAFE  Framework),  national  single  window  (NSW),  and  other 
information and communication technology (ICT) systems. Strong intercultural communication 
skills and experience in working in the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation (SASEC) 
subregion or other Asian subregions is considered highly advantageous. The expert will be 
based in the field and home office, and will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Provide technical support to the executing agency, national trade facilitation body 
(NTFB) for Bangladesh, and the National Board of Revenue (NBR) as team 
leader for the TA. 
(ii)  Help  develop  a  detailed  implementation  plan  for  the  overall  TA,  indicating 
scheduling of inputs and outputs and milestones, and assist in the recruitment 
and scheduling of other TA consultants and resource persons.  
(iii)  Assist in the institutional strengthening of the NTFB in Bangladesh, which will 
guide the overall national trade facilitation strategy. Provide technical guidance to 
the NTFB and develop the 2013–2016 national trade facilitation action plan. 
(iv)  Provide guidance to the overall work of the other international experts, national 
experts,  and  resource  persons,  and  oversee  their  assignments  and 
responsibilities, assuring timeliness and quality of project deliverables.  
(v)  Organize and oversee technical, training, and capacity building workshops and 
seminars  in  border management,  single  window,  risk management,  ICT  and 
other subjects as outlined in the TA, and work with World Customs Organization 
(WCO) experts in training activities with WCO involvement.  
(vi)  Undertake other management and liaison tasks as directed by the executing 
agency. 
(vii)  Help formulate necessary draft amendments to the Customs Act of 1969 and 
related legislation to make the act fully compliant with the general annex of the 
Revised Kyoto Convention (RKC). 
(viii)  Conduct  a  regulatory  impact  assessment  of  proposed  amendments  to  the 
Customs Act and related legislation to make them fully compliant with the general 
annex. 
(ix)  Help establish an authorized economic operators program.

2.  Customs Law Expert (10 person-months, intermittent)  
 
3.  The customs law expert will hold a graduate degree in law or other relevant field. The 
expert must have at least 5 years of working experience in drafting legal documents, preferably 
in a trade-related area, specifically customs. The expert will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Review relevant national legislation and procedural requirements that need to be 
revised or implemented and draft relevant modification of legislation, if required, 
to  conform  to  the  requirements  of  the  RKC,  SAFE  Framework,  and  NSW. 
Support the NBR in recommending necessary amendments to be submitted for 
approval by relevant authorities.  
(ii)  Assist in drafting a regulatory impact assessment of proposed amendments to 
the Customs Act and related legislation to make them fully compliant with the 
general annex of the RKC. 
(iii)  Provide guidance and assistance in all activities to identify and carry out legal 
and regulatory aspects of priority trade facilitation reforms in Bangladesh. 
(iv)  Carry out other tasks to be assigned by the TA executing agency. 
 
3.  National  Single  Window  and/or  Information  and  Communication 
Technology Specialist (12 person-months, intermittent)  
 
4.  The specialist will have experience in the application of information and communication 
technology (ICT) in a border operations environment, automated customs systems including 
ASYCUDA,  and  planning  ICT  systems.  Experience  in  trade  facilitation  ICT  operations  in 
developing countries is essential, preferably in a customs environment. The specialist will be 
based in the field and carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Develop a detailed design plan to pilot the NSW.  
(ii)  Develop a plan to improve online submission of forms and files to a central 
system to facilitate interministerial and/or interagency data sharing, and develop

Appendix 3  11 
easy steps for filing and clearing trade paperwork by private stakeholders, with 
the goal of moving towards a single window.  
(iii)  As part of the migration to ASYCUDA World, facilitate a secured interchange 
platform for data sharing between border checkpoints and central customs, and 
between border checkpoints. 
(iv)  Help  develop  the  interface  between  ASYCUDA  World  and  the  pilot  NSW 
program, connecting with the electronic data processing systems of selected 
agencies such as commerce and shipping. 
(v)  Plan and prepare the pilot testing of a new customs automation system in at least 
two border checkpoints. 
(vi)  Assist in the development of a trade portal, which is being undertaken by the 
Ministry of Commerce under the SASEC Trade Facilitation Program loan and is 
to be linked to ASYCUDA World. 
(vii)  Help the NBR develop a needs-based, modern, and secure ICT system. 
(viii)  Carry out other tasks to be assigned by the TA executing agency. 
 
4.  Risk Management and Post-Clearance Audit Specialist (12 person-months, 
intermittent)  
 
5.  The specialist should have significant operational experience in risk management and 
post-clearance audit systems in a customs environment. The specialist must have developed 
risk management systems and delivered specialist training courses on the subject, preferably in 
developing countries. The specialist will visit selected SASEC border checkpoints in Bangladesh 
and discuss with senior officials at their central administration the potential to introduce the 
concept on a pilot basis and carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Help the NBR develop and implement a whole-of-organization risk management 
framework that drives a philosophy of a risk-based, intelligence-led approach in 
its operations. 
(ii)  Undertake an initial assessment of the current application of risk management, 
post-clearance audit and pre-arrival clearance within the customs organization, 
with particular focus on its application at selected borders. Review all customs, 
tax, and trader databases and assist in the development of a risk register, along 
with an authorized economic operator scheme. 
(iii)  Lead  and  oversee  the  initial  preparation  of  a  pilot  risk  register,  followed  by 
examination of completed risk registers for compliance with international best 
practice, and for piloting at selected border checkpoints. 
(iv)  Identify how a post-clearance department or unit could be developed and seek 
support from central customs for its introduction on a pilot basis for selected 
traders. Assist in the preparation of post-clearance audit systems manuals. 
(v)  Identify how pre-arrival clearance can be introduced at border checkpoints and/or 
ports and coordinate with the ICT specialist in developing a proposal for the 
computerization of such information to facilitate electronic connectivity between 
border checkpoints that will expedite clearances. 
(vi)  Provide awareness training workshops to national and local working committees, 
as  well  as  local  border  personnel,  to  ensure  that  they  are  familiar  with  the 
concepts and how they could be implemented. 
(vii)  Develop a comprehensive report on design plan and implementation undertaken 
on risk management systems, and conduct workshops to share work with senior 
government officials. 
(viii)  Carry out other tasks to be assigned by the TA executing agency.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
5.  Transport and Transit Specialist (6 person-months, intermittent)  
 
6.  The specialist will have knowledge of and experience in international transport and 
transit operations. The specialist will have participated in the implementation of successful 
transport and/or transit agreements. The specialist will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Survey transporters providing international services along key SASEC corridors 
in Bangladesh to identify the nature of transport operating constraints including 
bonded transport arrangements, regulations pertaining to transshipment and use 
of bonded facilities at borders, and potential use of radio frequency identification 
tags and related technology, and catalogue existing and possible transport and 
transit agreements. 
(ii)  Examine  options  for  multilateral  vehicle  movement  agreements  to  facilitate 
SASEC trade and propose piloting by Bangladesh and neighboring countries.  
(iii)  Prepare a transport report detailing proposals for enhancement of transit and 
vehicle movement agreements between Bangladesh and neighboring countries, 
highlighting key benefits anticipated to be accrued in each country. 
(iv)  Organize national workshops with senior government officials on best practices 
in  international  transport  systems,  highlighting  beneficial  economic  spillover 
effects, and present proposals for enhancing transport and/or transit and vehicle 
movement arrangements in the SASEC subregion as detailed in the transport 
report. 
(v)  Carry out other tasks to be assigned by the TA executing agency. 
 
6.  International  Resource  Persons  (10  persons,  4.5  person-months  in  total, 
intermittent)  
 
7.  Ten international resource persons each to be engaged for 10 person-days (a total of 
100 person-days, or 4.5 person-months) will participate in training and seminar workshops to 
discuss  international  good  practices  and  provide  advice  on  specific  TA  outputs.  They  will 
provide  technical  and  capacity  building  support  and  serve  as  a  quality  check  for  tasks 
undertaken by the technical team. 
 
B.    National Consultants 
 
1.  Customs Experts (2 persons, 48 person-months in total) 
 
8.  National customs experts will be responsible for managing day-to-day liaison with the 
international consultants and the implementing agency. The experts will ideally have a good 
understanding of the trade facilitation environment in Bangladesh, particularly in relation to 
customs and border operations. They will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Assist in the strengthening of national trade facilitation bodies, and work with the 
team leader to develop their terms of reference and work plan and help secure 
approval of these by the relevant national authorities. With the team leader, 
develop a detailed overall national implementation plan in consultation with the 
national trade facilitation body, indicating scheduling of inputs and outputs and 
milestones. 
(ii)  Serve as the focal point for coordination between the implementing agency and 
ADB and the international consultants. Assist in the coordination of meetings and 
field  visits, facilitate  interministerial  coordination,  liaise  with  local  government

Appendix 3  13 
offices, arrange national workshops, and other tasks at the national and local 
levels.  
(iii)  Organize and oversee technical training and capacity building activities under the 
TA. 
(iv)  Provide  monthly  progress  reports  to  the  team  leader,  and  undertake  other 
management and liaison tasks as requested by the team leader or ADB's project 
officer.  
(v)  Carry out other related tasks as requested by the TA supervising unit specialists. 
 
2.  Trade Facilitation Coordinating Analyst (24 person-months) 
 
9.  The analyst shall have a graduate degree in economics, business, or related field, as 
well  as  experience  in  regional  cooperation.  The  analyst,  who  will  be  based  in  ADB 
headquarters, will provide technical and administrative support for activities to be implemented 
under the TA. Responsibilities will include the following:  
(i)  Provide secretariat and coordinating support for all TA-related activities, including 
administrative and communication tasks at ADB and organizing and updating TA 
information and data. 
(ii)  Develop and maintain a system to monitor progress in TA implementation. 
(iii)  Prepare  progress  reports  and  reference  documents  for  TA-related  meetings, 
workshops, and seminars, as well as other SARD meetings that include transport 
and trade facilitation in the agenda. 
(iv)  Assist with the preparation, publication, and dissemination of knowledge products 
coming out of the TA. 
(v)  Contribute  to  the  SASEC  program  website  information  relevant  to  TA 
implementation. 
(vi)  Organize regional meetings, seminars, and workshops related to the TA. 
(vii)  Carry out other related tasks as requested by the TA supervising unit specialists.
